segments.text: What's your message to all the young Virat Kohli's watching this and young Jemima Rodricks is watching this who will take the country further?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know, I'm so glad you used the second name.

segments.text: I think when I watch the women's league, like watching a new emerging kind of activity.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know Vikings would always invade with the women as well?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Okay, alright.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We need to be Vikings now.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You notice I'm not disputing it?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Why are you doing this podcast?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I'm doing this podcast because I like you.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: possibly the most requested episode we've had in the longest time because we've done so much geopolitical content and this legend has come up so much on the show that we just had to bring him on TRS.

segments.text: Keep in mind this is a very short episode.

segments.text: This was a great icebreaker with the legend.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: As I said earlier, I was a little nervous to speak to the cabinet ministers but Dr. Jayashankar made me feel extremely comfortable.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: That's his actual real life vibe if you're a young, motivated Indian.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And that's what this particular episode one with Dr. Jayashankar was about.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It was about the young, the new and the motivated India.

segments.text: I hope you enjoy this particular episode.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I hope every single young Indian watches this episode because to be honest, jokes apart, we're living through some intense times and we need to turn to people like Dr. Jayashankar for guidance about the future.

segments.text: So, I'm going to let you slip into the episode.

segments.text: It is a slightly shorter episode.

segments.text: But for now, enjoy this legendary piece of DRS.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well, I'm good.

segments.text: I've been busy for a few weeks.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But I would say probably people are more interested in foreign policy.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Nowadays?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Nowadays.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And maybe they'll come to watch you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, geopolitics is one of those subjects that people have been lapping up only recently, but lapping it up heavily.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And you're the poster boy for everything that's happening, correct geopolitically for India.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Okay, that's good to know.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But, you know, in a way, it's natural.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Look, what do we do most of the time?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You get up in the morning, first thing you do is reach out for your phone, right?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And see what is it you missed when you're sleeping.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What it's done is,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: has connected us completely to the world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And because of the phone and then you build everything around it, once you start getting used to global content and global comparisons, then what you eat, what you read, what you think, everything becomes global.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That's why they call it globalization.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Okay.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Simple question for you.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: who is Dr. S. J. Shankar the man that people don't know.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I'll tell you why.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Right now, you're very popular on shorts and reels for your very aggressive comebacks and your very aggressive responses.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And in many ways, I feel like Virat Kohli and yourself are the faces of young India in some ways.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: There's a slight age difference between us.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: No, but you're still the guy young India is cheering for.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: When we see you up there talking to all these people from other countries, we're like,
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: That's the response that they should get.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Look, you know, I'm a trained diplomat whose general SOP is, you know, keep it, play it cool, sort of don't make too many waves, et cetera.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Now, partly I've transitioned into being a political face, okay.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Even I would say the diplomatic side of me, which is still very deep.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: After all, I've done it for 45 years, maybe more now.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's like this, I'm very nice to people who are nice to me.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: When I get pushed, I think it's natural to push back.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And one of the things that has been happening to a bit is in the last year, year and a half, people have been pushing us a bit.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I feel, I mean, it's you raised, you brought up Virat Kohli and cricket analogy, you know, if you get a few bouncers, you want to do something with it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Hit that pull shot.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Okay.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know, when you say the sentence, when I get pushed, in many ways, your I get pushed is actually when India gets pushed and you are the personification of India on a global scale.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: No, he didn't exactly say adh-budh.

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I guess I didn't ask him after that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Okay.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I guess what he was really saying is, look, this guy has watched a lot of people come and go.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Uh, so he's seen a lot.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So maybe you should talk to him and ask him what, you know, what's different.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What's different?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yeah.

segments.text: About you.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: No, I don't think it was so much what he was talking about me.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: He was actually saying that, look guys, talk to him because he will tell you how much

segments.text: you know, the prime minister's visits have changed, how much foreign policy has changed, how much the country has changed.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So, it was more his...
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It was my thoughts rather than me as a subject that he was talking about.

segments.text: That's my take on it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think it's okay.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Whatever.

segments.text: Okay.

segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Okay.

segments.text: And he spoke about how after a certain point, because you've played so much cricket and you have so many experiences that you've had,

segments.text: Your pattern recognition improves.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Some people would call pattern recognition intuition or the sixth sense.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I am 100% sure that even on a geopolitical scale, there is a role of your sixth sense.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Absolutely.

segments.text: I agree with you.

segments.speaker: Host

segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I mean, I use that word cautiously.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: No.

segments.text: Look, what happens is there is...
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: This is partly experience.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: but it's partly also hard work.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Any business, again, we are using a sports, but I would use it in my own line of work.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You spend a lot of time reading other players, understanding their game, their play, how does it work, their mind games, which they try on you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So you try to see patterns in other people, in other countries,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: you know, other foreign ministries, et cetera.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Just like you do in sports.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So in that sense, there's something very, it's a competitive activity.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So if you're going up against a competitor, and I am a very competitive person, okay, I mean, when you ask me that bit, I absolutely let you know.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, I try to work out as much of it in sports, but I still have a lot left over for my real business.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So when you, when you, if you are a competitive person,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: all the time your sixth sense, as you call it, is working on your, you know, one part I'm listening to you, but if, you know, I've seen you do this before, we've talked before, I've seen, I've prepared by watching you or studying you before, the sixth sense takes over.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So sometimes, you know, when you are in a situation, people sometimes ask you saying, oh, did you think about that line before?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I didn't, I mean, that sixth sense takes over
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: at that time because you already kind of, you know, it's moving faster than your mind and it's actually telling you, okay, they're going to hit you with this.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So you're already processing it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So you, you, you see that coming at you before it actually comes at you.

segments.text: So that's the, I would say it's more like a instinct, right?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You call it spirituality.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I wouldn't go that far, but.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, there you have, but you know, I just want to round off the earlier point.

segments.text: You asked me what, you know, what did PM mean by that?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What has changed?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I think one part is we're really living under Prime Mr. Modi in a different era.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, he has been in many ways personally transformational.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: He's churned the system in a very, very radical way.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, I, you know, I joined the government when another Gujarati was a prime minister, Maraji Desai.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Okay.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So that's how far back I go.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: A lot of people, you know, your listeners would be wondering, okay, what the hell is he even talking about?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You're still the poster boy of young India.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But, but look, it's not often you get people in any line of business.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Leave alone in something like running a nation.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You can have the big thoughts, you know,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: the strategic ideas, the grand vision.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Very seriously, you have the revolutionary concepts that you chart out, okay, there's a different way of looking at a problem.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That's one skill.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And then you have going down to the details saying, okay, this needs to be tweaked, that detail needs to be looked at, this problem needs to be fixed.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Guys, you haven't done the backup on this.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Usually,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: there are talented people, inspired people who get the big picture.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: There are people who are very grounded, who kind of go down, drill down.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's very rare to find it in one person.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And that, I would say to me, is a very singular quality of Prime Minister Modi.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And that makes it very, in a way, very interesting to work with him, but it makes it very challenging because he can challenge you right up there.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: He can challenge you
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: right down there.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What's your current challenge?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Look, the world's a tough place right now.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We barely come out of this COVID thing.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You had this Ukraine conflict and all the consequences which came out of it, energy, food, inflation, fertilizer.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If we had not handled it well, the Indian consumer today,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: the average person, you and me, it would have actually hit us in our pockets.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We would have seen much higher inflation.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: We'd be paying much more for our oil than we are.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So I'm actually looking at a world where everything is coming at me at the same time.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: There's a health issue coming at me.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: There's an energy issue coming at me.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I have a set of border problems on the boundary border areas with the Chinese.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: pending the whole problem with the Pakistanis who have been doing terrorism for so long.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And at the same time, I'm growing.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: My people are traveling abroad.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And for me, one big part is how foreign policy is not a kind of a board game or an academic exercise.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It actually affects every person.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So in my own mind,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's like, how do I get this foreign policy for you, you personally, right?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: How do I secure you when you travel?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: How do I look after you when you get into problems?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: How do I make sure if you're a student that you can work on the side and support yourself?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Or that you don't have to wait for two and a half years for a visa by a foreign embassy.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So it's, as I said, I've also learned, it's the small things, it's the big things, you've got to get them both right.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The one truth I've learned about geopolitics is that it's money oriented.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: If you have the money, it helps you geopolitically.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: The second truth I've learned is that, and this I've learned in the last three days speaking to the cabinet ministers, is that the role of entrepreneurs is just do your own thing, create employment, increase the exports of the country, help the country become richer.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Would you like to give the youth and especially entrepreneurs any other geopolitical advice?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: When it comes to this, I don't want to use the phrase India versus China.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: But this whole scenario, how can we help?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: No, I look, I think you're smart not using that phrase India versus China for this reason.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yes, we have issues with China, but that's not the only issue.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I mean, we have to be fundamentally competitive.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If I do not have the factories, if I do not have the
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: the, as you say, the entrepreneurship, the businesses, the startup, the agriculture, the infrastructure.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It's not just the Chinese.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: The rest of the world will also run over me.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So, you know, it is at the end of the day, there are roughly 200 nations in the world.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Okay.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Okay.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Maybe about 125, maybe much smaller.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Okay.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: After that, once you start grading them, there will be a zone.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Okay.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: there'll be a zone of countries who constantly compete with each other.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: They could even be friends.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, the US and Europe are friends.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: They compete like hell, okay?
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So you'd have a Europe, you'd have an America, Russia, China, then you add, you know, maybe countries who are economically smaller than us, but they would compete in certain fields, you know.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So, I mean, say for example, you have a Vietnam.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: A Vietnam is a much smaller economy.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But the fact is Vietnam competes when it comes to certain kinds of investment.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So the bottom line, I think what the young people need to know is that today it is all about building strengths.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That when you say make in India, when you say startup India, when you say gati shakti, nobody's going to manufacture in India if your infrastructure is lousy.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So they need to see the smart ports, the good roads,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: the rapid movement of goods.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Now, if you have to do all this, if you really need to create jobs.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: To me, at the end of the day, it's all about creating jobs and opportunities.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: There are many roads to it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Even foreign policy, I would say, especially foreign policy, is one road, which is our job is also to market India, to brand India, to make India a magnet so that the rest of the world says, okay, these are responsible guys, these are safe guys.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Let's go and do business.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, they're not going to steal your stuff.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Okay.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Basically, chase excellence, create employment.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And as we move forward in this chase of individual excellence, you will achieve national excellence.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Absolutely.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: In the sport of global, I mean, in the global sport of geopolitics.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Absolutely.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Well said.

segments.text: Is your interaction with him, which the news doesn't capture, which only podcasts can potentially capture?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And what's your interaction like with, say, the Chinese foreign minister if you meet him?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Diplomacy is an art of detail in a way.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Okay, there's a lot of nuance, you know, body language, how you dress, what you say, how you look, how you hold your hands or don't hold your hands.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: All of this counts.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It depends on the person.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It depends on the situation.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It depends, you know, the national relationship.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Yes, yes, that also.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So you try to use, you try to use, it's a bit like a choreography.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So you use that occasion to do the signaling.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I could modulate it depending on that.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So it would depend on the situation.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So there are times and occasions.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I wouldn't say there's a single formula.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Okay.

segments.text: Very raw question for you.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: So, pardon me if I'm crossing a line.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: What's the most pissed off you've gotten at one of these meetings?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I'm sure something would have been said that just irritated you as a human being and what was your response?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: And you don't need a name or you can name if you wish.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: You know, rarely by personal things because mostly I've learned to absorb it.

segments.text: It sort of...
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I take its power for the cause for me.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: What happens is things do get under my skin.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I give you a recent example.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: I've spoken about it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: You know, I was getting, I was actually landed, I forget from Bangalore or something on a plane.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: And I saw this picture of this guy climbing up the Indian High Commission in London and trying to pull down a flag.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Absolutely.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: It got under my skin.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: So if people, you know, they try and score points, you know, personal points, I just shrug it.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: If I feel in some way the collective I, in some way is demeaned or attacked or something, yes.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That's when I said, when I get pushed, okay.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: That I, as you rightly said, is not me the I, but I the India.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: But that sense that somewhere, if you're not given the respect or if your people are condescending,
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Sometimes people ambush you.
segments.speaker: Guest

segments.text: Okay.

segments.text: And professionally, when do you feel the most alive?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Like when do you feel that you were born to do exactly this?
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: That's a feeling which kind of grew on me over a period of time.

segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: We're going to cover many more topics.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I'm going to ask him a lot more questions that Abhijit Chawda, Rajiv Malhotra, Abhijit Iyer Mitra have raised in my mind, but that's for the next time.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: For now, I request you to share this episode as much as possible.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: More cabinet minister interviews are coming up.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Thanks to My Gov India helping TRS crack these conversations.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Please give me your feedback, ladies and gentlemen.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I want to know what you thought of this conversation.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I want to know what we can improve and I want to know who else you'd like to see when it comes to this political phase of TRS.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I always try bringing out the human side of the person and I hope that you enjoy these conversations as much as I enjoy creating them for you.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Lots of love to you guys, lots of gratitude.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Dr. Jaishankar will be back on TRS.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Lots of love and gratitude and paribona to him.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Thank you, sir, for everything you do for the country.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: I hope to see you soon.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: It was an honor speaking to you and it's always an honor creating episodes for you guys.
segments.speaker: Host

segments.text: Ranveer, we'll see you soon, everybody.
segments.speaker: Host
